image.altText: a close-up of an aboriginal man in army uniform looking at camera

props.synopsis: In an era of spy satellites and nuclear submarines, Australia's vast northern borders are still being defended by squadrons of soldiers using techniques that are thousands of years old.

title.children: From a secret location in the Top End, these soldiers use ancient techniques to defend Australia

image.altText: a composite image one showing a flooded are with trees an looking green the other a sunset after a hot day

props.synopsis: Next week to bring a repeat of wild weather across many parts of Australia, after a surprisingly wet November.

title.children: East Coast Low makes way for severe thunderstorms, a December scorcher, and Coral Sea cyclone

image.altText: A woman with a trolley stands in a stocked supermarket aisle.

props.synopsis: The product feels lighter, or it's smaller, and you can't quite put your finger on the change… but there is a change. Shrinkflation is becoming more widespread, but can anything be done about it, asks David Taylor.

title.children: 'Shrinkflation' is becoming more widespread, but there's one thing shoppers can do to avoid it

image.altText: A person wearing a keffiyeh holds their fingers up in a peace sign, a Palestinian flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: What happened in the aftermath of the Sydney Theatre Company performance is a reflection of how the latest conflict in the Middle East has erupted into bitter and dangerous reductionism in political debates in Australia, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Three young actors took to the stage in keffiyehs. A bitter and dangerous debate was unleashed

image.altText: people carry someone on a stretcher while stepping through debris

props.synopsis: After the collapse of the week-long truce, fighting has resumed with Israeli warplanes pounding Gaza while Hamas sent rockets from the enclave into nearby towns.

title.children: Israeli leaflet drop warns southern Gaza of coming conflict

image.altText: COP primer - Oil derricks

props.synopsis: Talks about how to wean the world off fossil fuels are taking place in one of the globe's leading petrostates. Massive increases in green energy and who should pay will be up for discussion.

title.children: What is COP28? Here's what to expect at this year's UN climate talks

image.altText: A woman with black hair leans in to a man wearing a green jumper.

props.synopsis: The Kremlin is yet to comment on the alleged poisoning attempt on the wife of Ukraine's chief spy, but if Russian agents are involved, it suggests that Soviet era tactic remains alive and well in the new age of war.

title.children: Why female Putin critics from Russia and Ukraine might be the target of a new wave of poisonings

image.altText: Cleveland Dodd's casket being carried to his grave.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of mourners gather for the funeral service for the teenager who died inside WA's juvenile detention system.

title.children: Casket holding Cleveland Dodd's body lowered into the ground on Yamaji country after boy's death in custody

image.altText: A woman in a black suit and pink shirt with dark hair, is back to back with a man in a black suit and white shirt.

props.synopsis: Islamophobic and antisemitic incidents in Australia are at unprecedented levels as the Israel-Gaza war rages.

title.children: 'Hate attacks, death threats': Unprecedented rise in Islamophobia and anti-Semitism amid Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: A child leans on a scooter while his mother smiles down at him, inside a lift

props.synopsis: The number of no-kids zones in South Korea has exploded in the past decade, but some parents say it's creating a culture where children are unwelcome and restricted from learning how to behave in public.

title.children: South Korea is desperate for more babies — just not in cafes or restaurants, please

image.altText: Dave story

props.synopsis: The momentum of women's sport is in unstoppable motion, but the wages of some codes compared to others shows not all sports are created equal, writes David Mark.

title.children: Women's sport is rising faster than ever before — but which sports are keeping pace with wages?

image.altText: English singer-songwriter, Jessie Ware

props.synopsis: This week, singer Jessie Ware re-lit the disco fire in my soul enough to make me want to go out dancing. But where? There's no dance scene for women my age anymore – and maybe it's been ever thus, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: When you're on the 'wrong' side of club-ready, where do you go to dance?

image.altText: Pokemon characters on an advert

props.synopsis: A search for the operator of mysterious websites using unlicensed Pokémon branding to spruik an upcoming game has proved trickier than catching the Nintendo characters themselves.

title.children: When Pokémon tried to sue a company purportedly based in Western Sydney, it led to a global search for its operators

image.altText: Grey haired man wearing grey shirt putting on nasotracheal tube around nose and ears

props.synopsis: Giuliano Gaspri spent eight months in hospital with COVID. He's part of a study of long COVID patients which hasn't found the cause, but did find life can return to normal with time.

title.children: Long COVID research offers 'light at the end of the tunnel', finding symptoms ease over time

image.altText: Close-up of woman's face and hands putting on a mask during the coronavirus pandemic in Australia.

props.synopsis: We've been hearing about a rise in cases over the past month, but the eighth wave appears to have peaked in some jurisdictions. Let's get you up to speed.

title.children: Has Australia's eighth COVID-19 wave peaked? Here's the latest from each state and territory

image.altText: An in-flight picture of an airliner over a beach, the plane in purple and white livery showing the word "Bonza".

props.synopsis: Budget Australian airline Bonza cancels all December flights between Darwin and the Gold Coast, leaving families who purchased tickets exasperated, furious and now at the mercy of exorbitant flight prices to make it to their destination.

title.children: An airline's cancellation of all December flights on one route has devastated families' holiday plans

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair holding a sign saying she has had enough of domestic violence

props.synopsis: A large crowd has rallied in Darwin to call for more discussions about the scourge in the Northern Territory, which suffers from high rates of domestic violence.

title.children: 'We can't be silent anymore': Hundreds march against domestic violence as reforms pass parliament

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

props.synopsis: Australia's teachers are not equipped to deal with rising levels of disruption in classrooms, a Senate inquiry has found, while calling for students to be taught how to behave.

title.children: Teachers need better training to deal with increasingly disruptive school students, inquiry says

image.altText: Brittany Higgins outside court with an inset image of her going through Parliament House security.

props.synopsis: Brittany Higgins tells the Federal Court she tried to "reclaim" the dress she alleges she was sexually assaulted in by wearing it at a Liberal Party function in the months afterwards.

title.children: Brittany Higgins re-wore dress she was allegedly raped in to 'reclaim' it, court hears

image.altText: A blue, purple, green and red coloured bird feeding two baby birds, perched in a tree.

props.synopsis: With its soft, twittering tune and brilliantly bright plumage, the scarlet-chested parrot is one of Australia's rarely sighted birds that is rejoicing in recent rain in South Australia's Riverland.

title.children: After the floods comes the feast, as rare birds relish heavy rain

image.altText: A close up of Jim speaking in a suit and orange tie outside a building during the day.

props.synopsis: As Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers completes the finishing touches on his mid-year economic outlook, he’s been urged by his state and territory counterparts to make the GST 'no-worse-off guarantee' a permanent arrangement.

title.children: Jim Chalmers urged by states and territories to make GST arrangements permanent

image.altText: Pallbearers carry Cleveland Dodd's casket at the teenager's funeral.

props.synopsis: After a morning of confusion and anguish, Cleveland Dodd's funeral has begun, with WA authorities reversing an eleventh-hour decision to block his incarcerated father from attending.

title.children: Cleveland Dodd's funeral begins as father arrives back in town, after ban reversed

image.altText: The outside of the County Court of Victoria building.

props.synopsis: In 1984, Robert Barry chased down a 24-year-old woman and raped her in a "degrading" attack. Nearly four decades on, he has been sentenced in a Victorian court.

title.children: Forty-year-old rape case solved through 'Cold Case Freezer Project'

image.altText: The video shows Jeffrey McLaughlin holding the boy to the ground.

props.synopsis: The parents of a child restrained by the Tennant Creek mayor during a so-called "citizen's arrest" ask the Northern Territory's major legal service to take action against the mayor.

title.children: Parents want action taken against mayor for 'citizen's arrest' of child, after mayor defends conduct

image.altText: Man sleeping on the sofa in the living room at home.

props.synopsis: Understanding the science behind why some naps leave you groggy and others leave you revitalised might help you pinpoint the ultimate nap time.

title.children: Feel like a nap? Here's how to wake up feeling refreshed after a snooze

image.altText: Australian golfer Min Woo Lee waves to his fans in the crowd after finishing his round.

props.synopsis: Min Woo Lee is on track to complete a golden winning double after storming to a three-shot lead at the Australian Open golf championships in Sydney.

title.children: Min Woo Lee storms to three-shot Australian Open lead

image.altText: Elaine Crombie with her fist raised in the air in front of midden shells on mound of dirt in The 7 Stages of Grieivng

props.synopsis: The Sydney Theatre Company is again under fire after a video shows cast members of The Visitors calling for a Gaza ceasefire, but actor Elaine Crombie says the company knew about it.

title.children: Sydney Theatre Company knew beforehand of cast's pro-Palestinian statement after show, actor says

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman wearing a bright purple shirt, stands in front of overgrown orange trees on red sandy soil.

props.synopsis: A Central Australian Aboriginal community hopes to improve the health of residents and increase food security by re-establishing a once plentiful orchard that has fallen into disrepair.

title.children: Remote community strives to improve health by growing their own fruit and veg in APY Lands

image.altText: A group of people holding umbrellas

props.synopsis: A magistrate says the deaths of five teenagers in a crash in south-west Sydney last year were "completely avoidable" after jailing driver Tyrell Edwards for 12 years.

title.children: Gasps in court as Buxton P-plate driver jailed for 12 years over crash that killed five teenagers

image.altText: A man wearing a patterned shirt with his arm around a woman wearing a black top and bright pink scarf.

props.synopsis: State leaders are calling for the federal government to amend Commonwealth laws and allow telehealth consultations for patients seeking access to voluntary assisted dying services, in the wake of a Federal Court ruling.

title.children: In John's final weeks of life, travelling for voluntary assisted dying appointments was 'a very big ask'

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

props.synopsis: Does a product wrapped in earthy beige make you feel it must be environmentally responsible? New research shows how easy it is for marketers to imply their products are "sustainable" without necessarily backing it up.

title.children: These are the tricks advertisers use to fake sustainable products
